atoms.title: Introduction
atoms.text:
# Introduction

Welcome back! We’re excited that you want to move onto the next step of learning Android.

By the end of this course, you’ll be able to make an Android app with buttons and text fields that a user can interact with. Together we’ll make the Just Java app, which allows a user to fill out a form to order coffee.

atoms.title: Introduction
atoms.text: We picked this project because nearly every popular app involves accepting some type of user input and doing something with that data. For example, in a chat app, you type in a message and it gets sent to a friend. Hence, knowing how to accept user input is a critical milestone on the way to becoming an experienced app developer.

atoms.title: Introduction
atoms.caption: ROP Tutorial app created by student arpy_vanyan

atoms.title: Introduction
atoms.text: To build the Just Java app, we’ll introduce you to the basic fundamentals of Java and computer science, as well as how to debug and fix errors in the code. We’ll explore more of what the Android platform offers, by building more complex user interfaces, adding support for another language, and taking advantage of other apps on the device. We have a vocabulary glossary that accompanies this course, and if you need help, you can ask questions on the class discussion forum.

atoms.title: Introduction
atoms.caption: To build the Just Java app, we’ll introduce you to the basic fundamentals of Java such as Intents.

atoms.title: Introduction
atoms.text: If you’re just joining us for the first time, note that the content presented here used to be part of a larger course (called Android for Beginners), which got broken up into 2 courses. So this course will contain Lesson 2, Practice Set 2, and Lesson 3. If you aren’t sure how to create user interface layouts in Android with XML, we recommend that you first take the Android Basics: User Interface course and then return here. You should also have Android Studio already on your computer (if not, check out these installation instructions). As a reminder, this course is intended for people with little to no programming experience. Course topics include variables, data types, methods, classes, and object-oriented programming. If you’re an experienced developer already, consider checking out the Developing Android Apps course. We’ll be your instructors guiding you through the course, so let’s get started!

atoms.title: Introduction
atoms.caption: Katherine Kuan, Kunal Chawla, Lyla Fujiwara

atoms.title: Create a New Project
atoms.instructor_notes: *IMPORTANT* - The activity templates (timecode 0:48) have been updated in Android Studio Version 1.4. If you are using this version or newer, please select the "Empty" activity template (instead of the Blank Activity), which will generate files that match the content in this video. If you're having trouble creating a new app, check out the Troubleshooting Document.

atoms.title: Build Layout
atoms.instructor_notes: **Hint**: Google search for "button android" **Another Hint**: Look at the Common Views cheat sheet How to reformat source code How to rearrange source code Helpful keyboard shortcuts for Android Studio Hex color code for black is `#000000` **Another Hint**: Look at the Common Views cheat sheet Hex color code for black is #000000

concepts.title: Do Something When the Button is Clicked

atoms.title: Do Something When the Button is Clicked
atoms.instructor_notes: **IMPORTANT:** Note if you copy and paste the code, you must add your package at the top of the file (there's a comment about it). The package name can be found in the project's AndroidManifest.xml file. The package name our example uses is : *package com.example.android.justjava; * If after you add the package and still see a line through some of the words, just ignore it for now. The code should still work perfectly! --- Here are the words we introduced in this video: - Programming language - Java - Event-driven programming - Activity - Comments - Package name - Import statements - Class name - onCreate() You can look up their definitions in the Vocab Glossary.

question.title: Do Something When the Button is Clicked

concepts.title: Modifying First Lines of Java Code

atoms.title: Modifying First Lines of Java Code
atoms.instructor_notes: Here are the words we introduced in this video: - onClick - Execute - Method - Calling - Expressions You can look up their definitions in the Vocab Glossary. If you want to learn more about programming with Java, feel free to check out our Java course.

question.title: Modifying First Lines of Java - Quiz

atoms.title: Solving Math Problems
atoms.instructor_notes: Here are the words we introduced in this video: - Expressions You can look up their definitions in the Vocab Glossary.

atoms.title: Add TextViews for Price
atoms.instructor_notes: **Correction:**The quiz image at the end shows *displayPrice(View view)*. It should be *displayPrice(int number)*. Link to code for displayPrice method Make sure Auto Import is on: * For Windows, go to File > Settings > Editor > General > Auto Import * For Mac, go to Android Studio > Preferences > Editor > General > Auto Import Check all of the following options: - Show import popup - Optimize imports on the fly - Add unambiguous imports on the fly - Insert imports on paste → All Here are the words we introduced in this video: - Gist - Snippet You can look up their definitions in the Vocab Glossary.

atoms.title: The Need for Variables
atoms.instructor_notes: Here are the words we introduced in this video: - Variables - Robust You can look up their definitions in the Vocab Glossary.

atoms.title: Add Your First Variable
atoms.instructor_notes: Here are the words we introduced in this video: - Data type - int - Variable name - Assignment operator - Initializing You can look up their definitions in the Vocab Glossary.

concepts.title: Sometimes things don’t go as expected

atoms.title: Sometimes things don’t go as expected
atoms.text: # First Things First Awesome job on creating your first variable! We saw that creating a new variable could be done in one line of code. If we wanted to show the value of that variable, then we were able to display it on screen in a TextView. As we continue modifying more Java code, it’s completely normal to try something out, and have the app unexpectedly crash.

atoms.title: Debugging a Crash
atoms.instructor_notes: DDMS stands for Dalvik Debug Monitor Server, and is a tool in Android to help you debug your app. For more info, click this link. Here are the words we introduced in this video: - Debug - Crashes - Compile time error - Runtime error - System log - Stacktrace You can look up their definitions in the Vocab Glossary.

concepts.title: Chatting with Google's Alice Yang, Part 1

atoms.title: Hook Up Two Buttons
atoms.instructor_notes: **Hint:**  To create the increment and decrement methods in MainActivity, copy the submitOrder method and change its name.  Then modify the code inside the method to do exactly what you need.
